author: {'steamid': '76561197989102913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1251, 'last_played': 1659669895}
review:
This is a wonderful tool for working on orienteering skills, particularly compass work and learning symbology. The maps feel great and look beautiful, and the way the terrain affects your movements and creates an ability to genuinely feel lost creates a sincere immersion that is needed for this sort of game. There's a good amount of routes and the course builder allows for creative setup of controls anywhere in the map. More maps would be great, but imo what this needs is more people making routes. 

That being said, the big con here is the silence of the developer over the past year. There was mention on the website of an OCAD converter of sorts for users to create maps, as that was the direction he was wanting to go and be able to focus on improving the gameplay. I believe if anything can supercharge this game and take it to soaring heights, it is that converter being released. I have emailed the developer to find out the status of this. Here's to hoping it emerges, because I would absolutely love to pour hundreds of hours into this. It is that good.

Should you buy this? 

If you think you want it, then I say yeah, with the caveat that you will likely find yourself wishing for what everyone on here is looking for. 

If you are an orienteer yourself, I think this should be a no-brainer purchase as a tool for practicing when you are unable to outside. It's a fantastic way to keep the skills sharp.

review:
I have been a keen orienteer for over 30 years. This game is the closest you can get to donning a pair of o-shoes & a compass during the current lockdown due to CV19.

The representation is very good, including the drift whilst attempting to run on a compass bearing and the general ability to get lost/disorientated in a forest.

Thoroughly recommended to any orienteer or to someone who would like to get an understanding of the sport from their armchair.

I hope that additional maps &/or the ability to upload OCAD maps will be made available in future editions.  Some UK forests or areas of open moorland would be good to see.

review: The 40€ price is pretty high, but I assume this sort of game doesn't have a big audience, so the developers must fund the project somehow. I bought it during a sale for 20€, and I'm still not sure that it was worth it in terms of value, but I happily support the developers. The game did a very good job of recreating Catching Features in a newer engine, and there are some great new features too. I think the game can actually be a really good practice for beginner orienteers, as it isn't too different from irl orienteering. Unfortunately there are only 4 proper maps in the game right now, but at least those are quite big and exciting. You also have the ability to set courses, and try other players' courses, which is a relly nice feature. I hope the game will be further developed, as it can be a great tool for coaches. I'm not sure if it'll be able to attract non-orineteers, but that's just a matter of marketing.

developer_response:
Hi,
thanks for your review.

Regarding  bugs:
It would be great to report an bug if you have some problem on email specified in main menu. So it could be fixed if it's bug of course.

Turning while running feature:
I have explained this feature here (which is existing in Catching Features too):
https://virtualo.org/direction-disturbance-model/

Here is short passage from that text:
What is direction disturbance model and why we need it?

In real orienteering, it’s not easy to keep accurate azimuth. You must look at a ground, at a map, you are fatigued, you need to avoid obstacles. So many factors are considerably influencing your running direction accuracy.

Some factors are replicated in Virtual-O simulation, like avoiding obstacles or looking into map. But looking on the ground, fatigue or uneven ground is different beast.

And here comes direction disturbance model to “rescue” (to be fair it’s trying to destroy your race)

Nice day
Peter

author: {'steamid': '76561198041993191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 844, 'last_played': 1627933366}
review:
Sziasztok! 

Kettős érzések kavarognak bennem. Először is el kell mondanom, hogy megvan egy másik hasonló játék is, a Suunnistussimulaattori, amely a régi grafikája és az optimalizálatlansága ellenére is több lehetőséget tartogat, mint a szebb, bár szerintem szintén kicsit optimalizálatlan Virtual-O. 

Egyelőre 2 map-on futhatunk: Cseh köztársaság, Szlovákia, ezen kívül előcsalogatható a fejlesztési fázisban lévő Norvégia,  ha a beta-t telepítjük. A játék előnyére váljon, hogy viszonylag szép, a hangok nagyon hangulatosak. A járás hangokat érdemes max-ra húzni, mert olyan jó hallgatni ahogy a gally és egyéb dolgok ropognak a talpunk alatt. A 2 map sajnos kevés. A Cseh köztársaság sikerült szerintem a legszebben, a többin még lehetne dolgozni, a norvég mapról nem is szólva! 

A játék ideig óráig leköti az embert, hiszem van Steam WorkShop támogatás/course builder funkció, amivel saját útvonalat rakhatunk össze, de ez minden. Sajnos nagyon hiányzik, hogy OCAD mapokat tudjunk a játékba importálni, ezáltal tetszőleges (valódi) térképek alapján a játék legenerálna egy új mapot tereptárgyakkal, domborzattal együtt. Sajnos a Virtual-O ettől még nagyon távol áll, sőt! A készítő valamiért kézzel akarja elkészíteni az összes map-ot,  és mivel egyedül dolgozik a játékon, eléggé lassan halad a projekt. Ebből is adódik a másik nagy negatívum amit észrevettem, hogy sokszor a térkép tereptárgyai nem pont úgy jelennek meg ahogyan a térképen látjuk, illetve pont emiatt sokszor csak megtippelni tudom hogy hol vagyok valójában, nem 100%-os. 

Másik nagyon negatív dolog (nem csak én szerintem), hogy Contours a fejlesztő, valamiért mindezek ellenére a többi "versenytárs" szimulátor áraihoz igazítja az övét, és valljuk be a 40€ nem éppen baráti ár 2.5 mapért. Csak a nagyon fanatikus orienteering fanoknak ajánlom a játékot a jelenlegi állapotában! Persze haladnak a fejlesztések, csak lassan. Mindig jön valami új hír a játékról, nem halott a dolog! 

 Én személy szerint nagyon várom az OCAD támogatást a jövőben, mert nagyon sokat dobna a játékon és sok munkát levenne a készítő válláról is, miközben tudná a háttérben kézzel építgetni a többi helyszínt. Én a való életben is futok, érdekel is a tájékozódási futás. Személy szerint kedvelem a Virtual-O-t, éppen ezért pozitív értékelést adok a játékra. Összességében jó időtöltésnek tartom, már csak a hangulata, a grafika és a hangok miatt is. A Steam WorkShop és a játékosok által generált tartalom miatt pedig akár további hosszú órákra is lekötheti a tájékozódási futás iránt érdeklődőket. Én személy szerint várom a további fejlesztéseket. Pozitívan értékelem. A játék összességében jó! Igéretes!

author: {'steamid': '76561198403972123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3985, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2774, 'last_played': 1513171727}
review:
Virtual-o is the best, most realistic and enjoyable orienteering simulator that is made! I have almost only positive feedback from the game after over 50 played hours. The gaming experience is a lot more like real orienteering than it is in Catching features and in Suunnistussimulaattori (those two are also orienteering simulators).

Virtual-o i still an “early access” game, and that is true but not the entire truth. It is already totally ready for gaming! Some adjustments will be done in the future to the game that will make the gaming experience even better that it is.

The biggest “fear” for new and potential buyers are definitely that there is only 3 maps available at the moment. I can tell you from my own experience that it is not a problem! There is so many different ways to use the maps, the biggest thing is that there is a lot of different courses made on each map and anyone can do now courses whenever they want. Another thing that makes the gaming experience more diverse is that you can use different types of the same map (regular, less details and brown). 

There are more maps already under work so if there is someone that aren't willing to buy the game just for 3 maps, one can buy the game in a while when there is more maps to play with. (You should not do that because you can buy the game now and you will get the new maps and features as soon as they are made, you can also get them in a beta mode and be a part of developing the new maps and features)

I can recommend the game for everyone that are interested in orienteering or want to try orienteering!

If you're an orienteering fan this game is a must buy for you. If not but you like reading the map and want to try orienteering in comfort of your home you will like this game.  Graphics are suprisingly good for such a niche game, and running feels very realistic.  

Just be aware that the game is still in early access and as of now does have only two maps, but they are very well done. And there are plenty of courses availlable for the maps, so you will have plenty of hours of fun and the course editor is easy to use, so you can make your own courses easilly.

review:
Even though Virtual-O is only in Early Access at this point, the playability is already great, time just flies while playing. The graphics effects are awesome, especially when also turning on night/fog etc. It is possible to set your own courses on the existing maps as well, as well as playing somebody else's course. For active orienteers, I can clearly see how this can improve their orienteering in real life as well (I know it will improve mine!), in particular when it comes to map memory.

The main limit at this point is the availability of maps (there are only two). However, these two maps are quite extensive (and in particular the Czech one is hard), so I have many hours of play left before I know these to well (the availability of maps, and knowing them too well after a while, is a problem in "real" orienteering as well). Some features are hard to see (in particular ISOM 509 Narrow Ride, as well as controls in pits), but in general, the terrain rendering reflects the maps extremely well.

For players with no previous exposure to orienteering, of course there is a learning curve in learning the map symbols. I recommend using very easy courses that mostly follow trails at first (again just like a beginner would take up real-life orienteering). A suggestion would be to add some simpler maps, like urban orienteering sprint maps, but of course these would require additional rendering features.

I can strongly recommend getting and playing Virtual-O. I am not particularly fond of most computer games (just too boring after a while), but this one I know I will spend many hours with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120853865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 862, 'last_played': 1600768147}
review:
Virtual-O is still in it's early stages, but I do want to write a review on the game in Early Access. However some of the negative things I write here are hopefully gone within the next weeks and months. 

To start with the postitive feedback. This game is the best game in the world for orienteteerers to train on their tecnique. Old games like catching features, can't compare to the realistic terrains and map handling of this game. The graffic is outstanding compared to old games of the same genre. So for the people that can't get enough of orienteering, this game is a must buy. 

For me as both a hobby orienteerer and gamer, this game is perfect. but if I was only one of this things, I wouldn't recommend it, atleast for now. 

The reasons for this is that there are only two maps, and without the possibility to create your own terrain from your own maps, you will pretty soon feel that you have "completed" the game. I'm sure that the developer will get more terrains out soon, but the game isn't going to be really excellent untill you can run on your own maps. For example in your own home town. So the avarage orienteerer aren't really going to be completely satisfied with the game as it is right now. 

If I was only a gamer, this game would be so hard to learn properly. If you like a big challenge, maybe you would like it. And you would learn a pretty important skill to have in life. How to get from A to B using a map.

However, for most gamers this is not a game to buy, and I know that wasn't the intesions of the developer either. But I do personally belive that when the game is developed to it's final state. It has some potential to get some none orienteerers in to the game. But then there will have to be a course for beginners to orienteering that will learn you the basics of the sport. As of now,  this isn't really a part of the game. At least not good enough.

To end on a positive note. I do feel like I'm actually running orienteering while playing this game. That's how realistic it is. And that is why I recommend the game. 

I personally are going to play the game untill it's stops being developed. And if it in it's final stage are awsome. I'm probably gonna play it for decades.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269271428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2282, 'last_played': 1500506667}
review:
Bear in mind, it is an early acess game.
And like with any early access game, by purchasing it you will greatly support the development of the game and speed up the progress towards a final release.
The core game is really nice and though it lacks a bit of content now, I'm confident that the final product will provide a fully digitalised version of the sport orienteering.

Briefly:

Positives:
+convincing running simulation, just like running IRL
+graphics
+weather settings and night/day time settings
+online course and results sharing
+course replay, well done!
+customisable settings for map and course
+menus have a nice appearance, especially the earth screen when selecting country
+close interactions between community and developer

Negatives:
-limited content (so far), only two maps, no city scape terrains..
-online sharing is a bit messy
-no map converter
-match between map and terrain not always perfect

Targeted players: if you are aiming to learn orienteering, improve skills for the real sport in front of your computer or just want to compete in a digital version of the sport, this game is what you seek. If not, I don't see any reason for you to buy it.

in depth:

If you're looking for an orienteering simulator, this is it. The essence of orienteering is brought into this video game making it possible to sharpen your technical skills despite ailments that hinders you from doing it IRL. What makes the game really enjoyable is the online course and results sharing which challenge you to compete against other players. 

As for now the game only provides two different sets of terrain/maps which makes the experience a bit limited. Although the "orienteering" works nicely on these two maps, there is a lot of room for improvements when it comes to the different in-game menus. It's a bit bulky to work with, both finding your way through the different options and learning how to use the course builder takes time. There are some tutorials uploaded to steam and youtube to get you going faster. The online course list is a bit of a mess and not all courses uploaded by players seem runable even. The course builder does, despite it being a little tricky to comprehend at first, provide a lot of ways to customise the races you upload. There are certain presets of map appearance such as brown for example and beginner tools like position assistant to mention some of the features that you can add to your race.

The actual "orienteering simulation": The running seems very natural and the running speed vary with respect to terrain/map symbols as well as steepness of the ground just as it does when doing it for real. There is even direction disturbance applied to make you loose your direction when running through dense vegetation and so on. Obviously A lot of things have been taken into consideration when simulating the running in this game which makes it really convincing.
The map handling takes time to get used to however. You can rebind the keys if you want but there are a lot of commands to handle the map. I find it easiest just to use the "focus on current leg" and the "scroll" to manage my map handling. It takes practice however. But all in all, the game really accomplishes a good orienteering simulator, which makes it a great tool for practising in that sense.

Terrain: Very beautiful. There are a lot of options when it comes to weather and time of day which is really nice when you want to add a nice atmosphere.

When it comes to map generation: There is currently no map converter implemented and as I understand, there is no promise there will be one available to the ordinary user in the future either. The current maps coincides well with the generated terrain with the exception of some smaller height/brown details that I found to be missing while playing around. Hopefully the developer finds a way to respect those details, which probably were'nt on the lidar data from which the terrain was generated, during future map converting.

The Virtual-O community together with a very engaged developer makes it easy for you to ask questions and/or add your opinions to discussions held on either Steam or facebook forums. If you encounter problems with the game the support will help to resolve these as well as ask for any bugs you find. Interaction between user and developer is close which encourages progress of the game.

To summarise: 
There is stilll a lot of content missing and some rough edges that needs polishing before this game becomes a fully fledged orienteering simulator. But seeing as this game has just launched as an early access, with the quality it currently holds, I'm sure that the finished product will be well worth its price. The game is a bit expensive compared to other steam games and if you're hesitating about buying it I recommend to wait and see how it progresses. In the meantime I and those of you who decide to buy it will have a pleasant time running each others courses, competing to become the very best. This is really what holds the fun whilst the content is limited!
